Not to call anyone out in particular, but here‚Äôs a good example of a bitcoin influencer turning on Nayib Bukele, the ‚ÄúTrojan horse‚Äù presidente of El Salvador who pushed through legislation putting BTC on equal footing with the U.S. dollar, for experimenting with TRON. ‚ÄúIdiot!‚Äù  Bitcoin toxicity may seem like a trivial issue. That this battle is being taken up by someone who talks in the third person as some sort of cartoon platypus speaks to the absurdity. The internet is not ‚Äúreal life.‚Äù Twitter‚Äôs infinite scroll is infinitely dumb. But at the same time, udiverse ‚Äì the troll of trolls ‚Äì has a point.  Many a public figure has been chastised for stating views counter to the bitcoin mindset ‚Äì sometimes pushing them out of the fold. Best-selling author Nassim Taleb has been savaged (though he may have been asking for it), as have figures like the lovable Neeraj Agrawal. Some folks, like Bloomberg editor Joe Weisenthal, playfully engage the beast. But for many, being dogpiled by ‚Äúmaximalists‚Äù is an unnerving experience.  As bitcoin continues to gain prominence in the global economy and activity on the internet, it has also become central to some people‚Äôs sense of identity. Bitcoin is not just an asset to hold but a movement in which you participate. Extreme fanaticism conflates perceived attacks on the Bitcoin network to one‚Äôs sense of self. It also allows no quarter to people who haven‚Äôt yet ‚Äúgrokked‚Äù bitcoin, or may be troubled by its effects on the world.  Read more: The Node: I Don‚Äôt Understand Bitcoin Maximalism | The Node  As Wertheimer argues, the case for coin tribalism is wearing thin. In his reading, maximalism as we know it today took root in 2017, when the bitcoin community was divided over the question of block size. This was a mostly technical debate about changing a few narrow parameters of the Bitcoin source code, but it was at heart an argument about what Bitcoin is. Should developers pursue a ‚Äúdigital cash‚Äù system, or is bitcoin ‚Äúdigital gold?‚Äù  Those who took the former position and wanted more transactions per second, making BTC more usable money, they reckoned, were deemed bad actors. (There were legitimate concerns about increasing the block size: Bigger blocks would diminish the fee economy; true scalability would likely require layer 2 systems regardless of block size; perhaps most importantly, bigger blocks would make it harder to run a node, thereby diminishing Bitcoin‚Äôs decentralization.) Many former insiders were cast aside.  I‚Äôm a subscriber to the idea that Bitcoin is something of a ‚ÄúProtestant reformation‚Äù in the history of money ‚Äì stripping financial control from technocrats and empowering individuals to pursue their own path ‚Äì and think ‚Äúbitcoin maximalism‚Äù could justifiably be described as a puritanical turn. Bitcoin became a mind colony. Ideas about bitcoin hardened, the scope of acceptable debates shrunk and everyone slightly heterodox was now a heathen. Leaving aside the heavenly visions of hyperbitcoinization, much of this unfolded in good faith.  ‚Äú[S]eparatism used to be a fitting response, e.g., in 2017, when actual bad actors tried to hurt the movement,‚Äù Wertheimer said. ‚Äú[H]owever, 2021 is different, the new crowds aren‚Äôt trying to hurt anyone, and separatism doesn‚Äôt achieve the stated goal of ‚Äòeducating‚Äô anyone.‚Äù (Wertheimer did not respond to a request for comment.)  Wertheimer isn‚Äôt the only hardcore bitcoiner to soften his views. Eric Wall, a researcher and chief investor for Arcane Assets, has also recently begun striking out against toxic maximalism. Wall and I spoke earlier this month about how identities form in the crypto industry, what value they provide and the possibility of changing your mind. His is a story of personal transformation, but it‚Äôs not about any single individual‚Äôs beliefs ‚Äì not Wertheimer‚Äôs or Wall‚Äôs ‚Äì but about community orientation. It applies also to other forms of blockchain maximalism.  The strongest case for bitcoin supremacy is made by those who want bitcoin to succeed in becoming a universally accepted scarce asset.  ‚ÄúIn order for bitcoin to compete as this store of value, we need to make sure that it stays the number one asset. If Bitcoin gets replaced by Ethereum, and then Ethereum gets replaced by Solana [and that] gets replaced by whatever the next smart contract platform or cryptocurrency is, then it‚Äôs going to be very hard to make the case that we‚Äôve actually invented digital gold,‚Äù Wall said over Zoom.  That‚Äôs a position Wall will fight for ‚Äúuntil my last dying breath.‚Äù But creating an ‚Äúalternative to the fiat money we have‚Äù does not preclude the success of other blockchain-based applications or tools.  Wall is a thorough if sometimes uncouth researcher. By his own account, he has made enemies of every coin camp ‚Äì being labeled a Cardano, Ethereum and Bitcoin maximalist ‚Äì for asking tough questions about each chain. For years, he had been skeptical of Ethereum and believed that in time, through scaling solutions, Bitcoin could achieve the same functionality as the so-called ‚Äúworld computer.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI used to believe that Bitcoin should be the base layer of everything and we should just build layer 2 solutions on top ‚Ä¶ to add flexibility,‚Äù Wall said. Looking a little closer, however, Wall discovered that these add-ons failed to live up to their expectations. All, excluding the Lightning Network, reintroduced the problem of ‚Äútrust‚Äù that Bitcoin had solved (allowing parties to interact without an intermediary).  Read more: Why Hardnosed Bitcoiners Can Learn to Love DeFi | Matt Luongo  That wasn‚Äôt the case for Ethereum, which has suffered from its own expansion issues but found ‚Äúflexible,‚Äù ‚Äúfeature rich‚Äù and ‚Äúdecentralized‚Äù solutions like rollups. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs something that made me start to change my position on whether or not bitcoin was the only asset that had a role to play in the cryptocurrency ecosystem,‚Äù Wall said. Blockchains can be complementary systems, he said.  This position, both financial and ideological, put him ‚Äúat odds‚Äù with some bitcoiners. When asked why that is, Wall said that sometimes when people invest in a blockchain‚Äôs promises, ‚Äúthey feel as if they have no way of backing out or changing their mind in light of new information or evidence.‚Äù  But crypto markets are open 24/7, and markets account for all available information.  ‚ÄúWhen I realized this, the only thing that I had to do was to buy some ether [the native currency of the Ethereum blockchain] to be in alignment with my beliefs,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNow I‚Äôm not afraid of ether becoming successful.‚Äù

Î≥∏Î¨∏: The U.S. government sanctioned a crypto exchange for the first time last week, escalating its fight against ransomware and proclaiming that crypto regulation will not be free of enforcement actions. My colleague Muyao Shen explores this issue and what the broader lessons may be for the crypto regulation landscape.  You‚Äôre reading State of Crypto, a CoinDesk newsletter looking at the intersection of cryptocurrency and government. Click here to sign up for future editions.  OFAC ramps up crypto regulation  The narrative  The Treasury Department‚Äôs Office of Foreign Asset Control (OFAC) is taking on the ransomware fight, sanctioning a crypto exchange for the first time.  Why it matters  OFAC‚Äôs role in the ransomware fight is interesting. It‚Äôs a sanctions enforcer, not a cyber watchdog. While it makes sense that the agency has a role in trying to mitigate the ransomware crisis, the fact it‚Äôs involved in the most public action against ransomware to date may actually reinforce one of the core ideas within the crypto sector: that intermediaries are points of failure.  Breaking it down  Last week, the OFAC blacklisted a crypto exchange for the first time on allegations it facilitated bitcoin transactions for ransomware actors. Suex, an exchange that claims to operate out of the Czech Republic but with offices in a handful of Russian cities, became the latest crypto entity to join the Specially Designated Nationals (SDN) list on Tuesday.  It‚Äôs the first formal action the U.S. government has taken in its fight against ransomware under the current administration, though Treasury has sanctioned people for facilitating cryptocurrency transactions on behalf of ransomware attackers in the past.  It‚Äôs also the first time a crypto exchange has landed in OFAC‚Äôs crosshairs.  Treasury officials did not respond to a set of questions about the action or the exchange.  ‚ÄúTreasury is announcing that we will now also be taking steps to obstruct and deter these criminals by going after their financial enablers,‚Äù Deputy Treasury Secretary Wally Adeyemo said in a press call previewing the action. ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs action is a signal of our intention to expose and disrupt the illicit infrastructure used in these attacks.‚Äù  Suex was a nested exchange, Adeyemo said, which blog posts from TRM Labs and Chainalysis described as an exchange that doesn‚Äôt operate its own custody service but uses a larger exchange to tap into its liquidity and market-making abilities.  In this case, Binance appears to be one of these larger exchanges. CEO Changpeng Zhao said Suex accounts were ‚Äúde-platformed‚Äù based on analysis of the 25 crypto addresses included in last week‚Äôs action.  There are a number of details about this action that really stood out to me. First, while the TRM and Chainalysis blog posts identified a handful of Suex‚Äôs employees and described their operations, OFAC did not add any of these individuals to its SDN list.  In contrast, when OFAC sanctioned alleged North Korean hackers, alleged Chinese drug traffickers or alleged Iranian crypto transmitters, the enforcer named the specific individuals involved in the illicit activities.  That hasn‚Äôt stopped Suex founder Egor Petukhovsky from saying he‚Äôll take on the U.S. government in court. He wrote on Facebook that none of his business entities engaged in illegal activity.  Still, regardless of whether Petukhovsky or the rest of the Suex team knew what transactions they were facilitating, the fact that reportedly around 40% of Suex‚Äôs transactions went to known addresses tied to malicious actors may be enough for the U.S. government.  It‚Äôs also interesting to me that OFAC swung what appears to be one of the first offensive blows against ransomware attackers. We‚Äôve known for a while that actions against crypto exchanges were on the table ‚Äì officials have been warning about this for months now ‚Äì but I wasn‚Äôt able to find a comparable action by the Department of Homeland Security, for example.  Past precedent?  The closest I could find are rumors the U.S. government may have been involved in the REvil ransomware group going offline, but nothing definitive.
